title: Lavender Tallow Balm: What Actually Happened to My Winter Skin
body:
Look. My face was a disaster. It’s winter, right? And everything just… gave up. It was like that dry, tight feeling you get after a long flight, but all the time. And it was flaky. Not cute. I tried everything. The fancy La Roche-Posay stuff my friend swore by. The CeraVe tub everyone on the internet loves. Even slathered on some Aquaphor like a greased pig. Nothing. It either sat on top of my skin feeling weird or just vanished and left me back at square one. I was scrolling on my phone at like 1 AM, my face feeling like parchment, and I saw this thing about beef tallow balm. For your face. I laughed. Out loud. My cat looked at me. Beef fat? On my skin? It sounded like something my great-grandmother would have used, not a modern skincare thing. But my skin was so mad at me. I was desperate. So I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I ordered this whipped tallow balm with lavender from some small shop on Etsy. A last-ditch thing.

## How I Started Putting Beef Fat on My Face

I need to back up. The whole situation was very… beige. My skin was beige. My mood was beige. It was that point in February where you forget what the sun looks like. My hands were cracked from washing them a million times a day. My cheeks had these rough patches that no amount of gentle exfoliating would touch. I remember staring at my reflection in the microwave door—it was Tuesday, I think—and just sighing. I’d spent so much on products in pretty packaging that did absolutely nothing. It felt stupid. So when the tallow balm arrived, I was skeptical. The jar was small. Simple. It came in a little cardboard box, no fancy marketing. I opened it. It looked like… whipped butter. That’s it. I poked it. It was firm but soft. I smelled it. Lavender. But not the fake, candle-store lavender. This was different. More herbal. Like the lavender plant my neighbor tries to grow but the rabbits always eat. It was calming. I was still skeptical. I washed my face, patted it dry, and scooped out the tiniest bit. I rubbed it between my fingers to warm it up. It melted. Like, instantly. I braced myself for this heavy, greasy feeling.

It wasn’t that.

It just… sank in. My skin drank it. There was no film. No shiny residue. Just my skin, but not screaming at me. For the first time in months, it didn’t feel tight. It felt quiet. I sat there on my couch, half-watching some baking show, just touching my cheek. It was soft. Not “product” soft. Just… skin soft. I was shocked. I didn’t say anything to anyone for a week because it sounded insane. “Oh yeah, I put rendered cow fat on my face and it’s great.” But I kept using it. Every night. The scent, that lavender, it became part of my bedtime thing. It’s not a strong perfume. It’s just this quiet, herbal smell that tells my brain it’s time to shut off. My cat still judges me, but less.

## Why Beef Tallow for Skin Actually Makes Sense

So I had to look this up because I was so confused why it worked. Turns out, it’s not that wild. This tallow balm is made from grass-fed beef suet, whipped up into this airy texture. They make it in France, apparently. The sciencey part—and I’m paraphrasing from a blog I read while waiting for my laundry to dry—is that the fat profile is really similar to the oils our own skin produces. Our sebum. So instead of just sitting on top like a silicone-based cream, it recognizes it. It gets absorbed deep down. It’s like giving your skin something it actually knows how to use. It makes a stupid amount of sense when you think about it. We’ve been putting all these complex, lab-made chemicals on our faces, and maybe the answer was simpler. Older. My grandma probably knew this. She probably had a jar of something similar next to the stove.

Anyway, my coffee is getting cold. The point is, it’s not magic. It’s just compatible. For winter damage, for dry skin that feels like the Sahara, for rough hands after gardening… it works because it’s fixing the barrier from the inside out. Not coating it from the outside. I started using it on my knuckles and elbows too. Game changer. My hands don’t look like they’ve been through a woodchipper anymore.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Tallow

I don’t want to sound like an infomercial. But honestly. The change was slow but real. After a few weeks, those rough patches on my cheeks were just… gone. Not covered up. Gone. My skin felt resilient. Like, I could go outside in the wind and it wouldn’t immediately revolt. The constant tightness was a memory. I even stopped wearing foundation because what was I covering? My skin just looked… healthy. Not “glowing” in that weird Instagram way. Just calm. Hydrated. Like it was finally getting what it needed. I remember meeting a friend for coffee and she asked what I was using. I mumbled something about “a balm” and changed the subject because I still felt silly. But I was smiling inside. This little jar from that Etsy shop, **Eesti Tallow**, was doing more than my entire previous skincare shelf.

Here’s a random tangent. The lavender scent. It’s not just for smell. I looked it up one night. Lavender’s supposed to be calming, good for sleep, all that. I don’t know about the science, but the ritual of putting it on at night… it does something. It’s this timeless, herbal smell that feels ancient. It signals my brain to unwind. My anxiety before bed, that buzzing feeling, it dials down a notch. Maybe it’s placebo. Maybe it’s the tallow fixing my skin barrier so I’m less stressed. Who knows. All I know is I sleep better. My skin is better. It’s a whole thing.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. I got one for my mom too for her dry hands, and she texted me last week saying she’s obsessed. She called it “that magic cow butter.” I guess the apple doesn’t fall far. For natural skincare that actually *does* something, not just talks about it, this is it. It’s not cheap, but the jar lasts forever because you need so little. And it replaced about three other products for me. So in the end, it’s a win.

I don’t have a dramatic before-and-after story. Just a slow, real improvement. My skin isn’t perfect. I still get a pimple. But it’s not a desert anymore. It’s just… skin. Happy skin. And in the middle of winter, that feels like a miracle.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, feeling tight, looking flaky, and the usual stuff isn’t cutting it… this might be worth a shot. I was skeptical too. But sometimes the simple, weird-sounding thing is the answer.

---

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. The idea freaked me out too. But the logic checks out—it’s very similar to the oils our skin makes naturally. So it absorbs way better than a lot of synthetic creams. It’s like giving your skin food it recognizes.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I’m prone to clogging. Because it absorbs and doesn’t just sit on top, it seems to actually help balance things out. My skin feels clearer, not more congested.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It’s a real herbal lavender. Not sweet or perfumey. More like crushed lavender plants. It’s calming and subtle—fades pretty quickly after you put it on, but that initial scent is really nice for winding down at night.
